articles.headline: Strong Economy Propels Brazil to World Stage
articles.snippet: Brazil, South America’s largest economy, is finally poised to realize its potential as a global player, economists say.
articles.abstract: Brazil, South America’s largest economy, is finally poised to realize its potential as a global player, economists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORTALEZA, Brazil  Desperate to escape her hand-to-mouth existence in one of Brazil’s poorest regions, Maria Benedita Sousa used a small loan five years ago to buy two sewing machines and start her own business making women’s underwear.

articles.headline: Olmert to Quit After Elections in September
articles.snippet: Embroiled in a corruption inquiry, Israel’s prime minister says he will resign as soon as his party chooses a successor.
articles.abstract: Embroiled in a corruption inquiry, Israel’s prime minister says he will resign as soon as his party chooses a successor.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, embroiled in a high-profile corruption investigation, announced on Wednesday that he would resign after his party chose a new leader in September elections.

articles.headline: McCain Tries to Define Obama as Out of Touch
articles.snippet: Veterans of President Bush’s 2004 bid are coordinating an effort to create a negative narrative about Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: Veterans of President Bush’s 2004 bid are coordinating an effort to create a negative narrative about Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After spending much of the summer searching for an effective line of attack against Senator Barack Obama, Senator John McCain is beginning a newly aggressive campaign to define Mr. Obama as arrogant, out of touch and unprepared for the presidency.

articles.headline: Earpiece in Place? Listen Up
articles.snippet: Two companies produce small, wireless earpieces that allow for hands-free, spoken conversations between you and the Impossible Missions Force.
articles.abstract: Two companies produce small, wireless earpieces that allow for hands-free, spoken conversations between you and the Impossible Missions Force.
articles.lead_paragraph: You know all those movie scenes where the hero must infiltrate a highly secure enemy facility? A normal person thinks something like this: “Oh, my goodness  I sure hope he manages to get through all those lasers and motion detectors! He’s the hero, and therefore I fear for his well-being!”

articles.headline: China’s Shift on Food Was Key to Trade Impasse
articles.snippet: The negotiations foundered on the right of developing countries to protect critical agricultural products from competition in exchange for cutting tariffs on imported industrial goods.
articles.abstract: The negotiations foundered on the right of developing countries to protect critical agricultural products from competition in exchange for cutting tariffs on imported industrial goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Some blamed soybeans. Others blamed cotton. And many pointed a finger at America’s election-year politics.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Terrible Timing for a Hotel Boom
articles.snippet: High gasoline prices and a slumping economy have put a damper on leisure and business travel, yet a record number of hotels are opening this year.
articles.abstract: High gasoline prices and a slumping economy have put a damper on leisure and business travel, yet a record number of hotels are opening this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: A record number of hotels are opening this year, and the timing could not be worse.
articles.byline: By Abha Bhattarai and Fred A. Bernstein

articles.headline: Amgen Told to Reword Drug Label
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration has ordered Amgen to change the labels for its flagship anemia drugs in a way that could further restrict their use in treating patients with cancer.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration has ordered Amgen to change the labels for its flagship anemia drugs in a way that could further restrict their use in treating patients with cancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has ordered Amgen to change the labels for its flagship anemia drugs in a way that could further restrict their use in treating patients with cancer.

articles.headline: A Hidden Toll on Employment: Cut to Part Time
articles.snippet: The number of Americans who have had their hours chopped is the largest since record keeping began.
articles.abstract: The number of Americans who have had their hours chopped is the largest since record keeping began.
articles.lead_paragraph: The number of Americans who have seen their full-time jobs chopped to part time because of weak business has swelled to more than 3.7 million  the largest figure since the government began tracking such data more than half a century ago.
